<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 568, 88]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 105, 783, 124]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 154, 675, 172]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 201, 685, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 245, 680, 273]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 685, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 348, 680, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 368, 560, 401]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 445, 227, 461]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 435, 905, 475]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 482, 771, 524]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 219, 571]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 552, 668, 595]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 631, 219, 647]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 628, 575, 707]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 740, 159, 756]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 736, 555, 788]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{align*} \sin^2 A + \cos^2 A &= 1 \\ \sec^2 A &= 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cos e^2 A &= 1 + \cot^2 A \end{align*}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 241, 844]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 822, 577, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{align*} \frac{a}{\sin A} &= \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 &= b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta &= \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C \end{align*}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 72, 666, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculators must **not** be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 110, 104, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 110, 136, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 590, 129]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\overrightarrow{P Q}=\left(\frac{-3}{7}\right)\) and \(4 \overrightarrow{P R}=\left(\frac{-2}{8}\right)\), find \(\overrightarrow{R Q}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 110, 916, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 424, 136, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 424, 917, 456]]<|/det|>
The vectors \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\) are such that \(\mathbf{a}=\alpha \mathbf{i}+6 \mathbf{j}, \quad \mathbf{b}=4 \mathbf{i}+\beta \mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{c}=(2 \alpha+5 \beta) \mathbf{i}+20 \mathbf{j}\), where \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are scalars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 469, 563, 485]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{c}=3 \mathbf{a}-2 \mathbf{b}\), find the values of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 469, 916, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 101, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 368, 89]]<|/det|>
Point \(A\) has coordinates \((3,-1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 98, 472, 118]]<|/det|>
A circle has equation \(\left(x-4\right)^{2}+\left(y+3\right)^{2}=5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 138, 136, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 556, 154]]<|/det|>
Show that \(A\) lies on the circumference of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 916, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 264, 136, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 264, 677, 280]]<|/det|>
Given that \(A B\) is a diameter of the circle, find the coordinates of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 264, 916, 280]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 620, 136, 636]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 620, 544, 636]]<|/det|>

<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 80, 411, 96]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 80, 916, 96]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 418, 422]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 427, 567, 460]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
\lg (x+2 y) & =0 \\
x^{2}+4 x y+y & =1 .
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 455, 916, 471]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 848, 160]]<|/det|>

Continuation of working space for Question 9.

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 75, 848, 107]]<|/det|>
Given that \(0 \leqslant \theta < \frac{\pi}{2}\), show that \(\frac{\sin \theta}{\sqrt{\cos e^{2} \theta-1}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}}\) can be written as \(\sec \theta\). [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 500, 136, 516]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 707, 518]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\sec x=\alpha\), where \(\frac{3 \pi}{2}<x \leqslant 2 \pi\), find \(\sin x\) in terms of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 916, 516]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 528, 104]]<|/det|>
<pre>11 An arithmetic progression has common difference \(d\). The 3rd term of this progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 758, 150]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label> Write down expressions for the 1st term and the 2nd term of this progression. Give your answers in terms of \(d\) only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 916, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 290, 136, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 290, 737, 322]]<|/det|>
When each of the first 3 terms is squared, the sum of these squares is 140 . There are two possible values for \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 917, 367]]<|/det|>
Using your answer to part **(a)**, find the sum of the first 200 terms of the progression with the smaller value of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 353, 916, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]
